Explanation: To determine if an argument is logically valid, we need to examine the structure of the argument and see if the conclusion follows necessarily from the premises. In this case, the argument has the following form:

If P, then Q
Q
∴ P

Where P represents "The griffin was in the forest" and Q represents "The unicorn was in the forest".

This argument form is not logically valid. The first premise only guarantees that if the griffin was in the forest, then the unicorn was also in the forest. It does not guarantee that the presence of the unicorn in the forest implies the presence of the griffin. There could be other reasons why the unicorn was in the forest, unrelated to the griffin's presence.

In fact, this argument form is a classic example of a logical fallacy called "affirming the consequent". It assumes that because the consequent (Q) is true, the antecedent (P) must also be true, which is not necessarily the case.
